captions.text: - [Voiceover] Are we ready?
- I think girls probably experience it
fresh out the womb.

- Can't escape it. Like,
you're born into it.

- I think you always know,
even when you're little
that pretty and not pretty are two things.

- The way that we talk
to young girls as adults
always involves looks.
- Girls spend most of our adulthood
trying to get over the fact that

when we were young, all that
we were told to be was pretty.
- Oh God, I think it's,
I think the pressure of pretty is coming
from so many different places.
It's media. Media affects men.
Media affects women. I think it's a cycle.

- A lot of my experiences
about being pretty
have to do with boys and whether or not
they thought I looked nice.
- It can really like mess up you at first.

You be like, "Well, what?
Why am I not good enough?

"Why am I not pretty enough?
Why am I not cute enough?"
- I needed validation from a guy
or a good looking guy to feel that way.
- Yes, I definitely think there is.

It would be nice if
they were all wrapped up
in the same thing, but I think beauty
is all over you.

- It's something that
comes from the inside out.
It's a combination of who I am
and what I bring to the table.

- Beautiful is something that
can't be taken away from you.

I feel the most beautiful
when I'm using my mind
and when I'm with my friends.
- Being around people who appreciate me

for every ounce of what I
am makes me feel beautiful.
- I feel beautiful when I'm happy.
- Being able to say that like,
at the end of the day, I still don't care
what anyone thinks.
I am who I am and I love that about me.
- I feel you, girls. It's not easy.

- Everyone, even the people
you think are super pretty,

has felt that way before and
you will feel more pretty

and more beautiful if
you focus on the things
that make you feel happy and beautiful.
- Try and find your own inner beauty.

- Find things that make you
feel good about yourself.

- Surround yourself with people
who think you're beautiful,

who think everything about
you is actually beautiful,
like the real you.

- Be a person that you
want to be and I think
that will make you happy and pretty
won't matter anymore.

title: What It Means To Be Pretty

comments.text:
I always get this stupid feeling when I'm home alone, getting ready to go 
party with my girls or just heading to the city. I don't wear make up very 
much, in summer, mostly only powder and some mascara, that's it.

But that stupid feeling is, that when I'm at home, looking myself from a 
mirror, I feel like "oh my, am I feeling pretty right now?! Oh yes I am!" 
Then I get to the city, and no matter who, every girl just seems to look so 
gorgeous! And then i get this "Omg people, why u all so beautiful?! It is 
not fair! I just spent some of my time to get to look like a human being 
and all of u are like gods and goddesses descended from heaven just to mock 
me!"-feeling XD﻿

comments.author: Nix VavaBear

comments.text:
The best thing you can do to feel beautiful is to give others the room to 
feel that way too.
You can blame the media all you want but in the end, we as consumers, no, 
fellow human beings are the ones that shape the media landscape with our 
insecurities and your need to look up and down onto others. So, stop it.
You remember the one time you said something mean about a girl/boy in your 
class or office? Remember the time you made assumptions about someone you 
don't know? I understand this basic human trait, the need of 
ingroup/outgroup thinking but that does not make it alright and it 
certainly does not help you in any way. So, again, stop it.

It's important that you feel good about yourself but don't put that task 
onto others, even if it is the media. Try to be a decent person who lets 
others be what and who they are, learn and teach, be fascinated and focus 
on that wonderful grey wobbly think in your skull... Rest assured that it 
will make you all the more pretty.﻿

comments.text:
I don't remember how little I was when I realized the concept of being 
pretty mattered. But in one of my earliest memories (I want to say age 3) I 
remember overhearing my Mom, Aunts, and some of their friends talking about 
what was pretty, then I remember rushing to a mirror to see if I had those 
traits and being sad when I realized I didn't meet them. 

On a different occasion (I want to say age 5). I was playing on my own and 
saying that I was a pretty mermaid. One of my sisters overheard me and told 
me I wasn't pretty.

At some point in my childhood I accepted the fact I wasn't pretty. In the 
nature of sour grapes, I told myself I didn't want to be pretty anyways. 
And because I felt I wasn't pretty, I didn't do anything to fix myself up 
because I'd still be ugly anyways. Of course, this made me look worse in 
comparison to all my peers who were wearing pretty clothes, had fixed up 
hair, and wore nice makeup. I didn't get any reinforcement from my peers, 
and was actually bullied for how "ugly" I was in middle school. 

Now I'm in college and I'm just starting to realize I'm not as ugly as I 
have always believed I've been. I don't feel pretty; but I realize I'm not 
ugly. I realize that the beauty standards my elders follow are just that: 
standards. And that people usually praise features that are unique, but 
having basic features doesn't make you ugly.

I also realize that my peers were cruel because we were at an age of 
conformity, and the negligence of my appearance is what made them look down 
on me (not trying to justify it.)... I've also realized I'm cuter than the 
sister who called me ugly, so there's that :)﻿
comments.author: theblackrainbow21

comments.text: Make others feel beautiful and you yourself will overflow with beauty ﻿

comments.text:
This made me cry. All my life, I've been compared to other girls, 
regardless of my achievements. That led to my insecurities. My best friend 
caused me the biggest one. She was a nice person, but when it came to 
attractiveness, she pushed me down. She called me fat and asked me to never 
have a child just in case she or he turned out like me. That almost killed 
me inside. I stopped talking to her. Before I did, I told her that even if 
my children come out with three legs or extra fingers, I would love them 
with all my heart. It's been five years since I stood up to her, and I've 
been happier than ever.﻿

comments.author: Karen Alfonso

comments.text:
Why doesn't anyone ever acknowledge that our parents are the first source 
of how we feel about ourselves?  The way they talk to us, the way they 
treat us, and the way our parents feel about themselves-it all has an 
impact on us as children.  Media affects parents, sure, but parents pass it 
down to infants, toddlers and kids.  How many times have you told (or seen 
friends with kids tell their children) they are pretty, or handsome. We 
start at infancy with these messages, treating and talking to girls like 
porcelain dolls and boys like baseball sluggers.  What chances do we really 
have to feel good about ourselves when we get these messages so young in 
life?  Instead, perhaps we should be telling our children that they can be 
pretty/handsome or not, and that it does not matter.  What matters is how 
you feel about yourself.﻿

comments.author: Bobby K

comments.text:
I so badly wish I could go back and talk to my 10-15 year old self. I'm a 
size 12/14 and have been since I was about 12 or 13 years old. I didn't 
start feeling decent about myself until I was probably 16 or 17 (which is 
when I started to care less about how other people perceived me). But for 
the longest time, I felt like shit about my weight and my acne. I've 
realized that I didn't begin to feel good about myself until I started 
distancing myself from my female friends in middle school and high school. 
My guy friends are the least judgmental, most positive influences I could 
possibly ask for, and they've changed my outlook dramatically. Girls can be 
so nasty to one another, and most of the time, it's not even apparent. I 
didn't realize how much my "best friend" in high school was tearing me down 
until we grew apart. She contacted me recently, apologized for how she 
acted toward me in the past, and we've tried to mend things. But in all 
honesty, I don't feel like thing have changed at all. Something tells me I 
need to part ways with her for good.

But yeah, surround yourself with people who never comment on appearances or 
compare themselves to you! You'll be so much happier!﻿

comments.author: rheanne kitten

comments.text:
I'd like to add that the difference you learn from the beginning about 
who's pretty and who's not, comes from you family first. As for my 
experience, my parents always compared me to my other cousins telling my 
"why can't you be thin like her", "why can't you leave you hair long like 
her", "why can you be like her". Since I was naturally bigger, higher than 
all my other cousins, and since I liked to play and run and wasn't really a 
"little princess", these comparisons happened all the time. If people tell 
you once or twice "why can't you be like her", you tell yourself "who 
cares, I don't", but if you listen to your own mom and dad telling you this 
stuff for years and years, you start asking yourself "why can't I be like 
her", i.e., pretty, thin, long hair, wear high heels, etc, etc.﻿

comments.text:
I've lately been pretty harsh on myself because of this one guy I like... I 
keep on having these thoughts in my head, saying "Maybe he likes me back?" 
but hope always falls apart when I look at the girls he's surrounded with, 
who are all tall and skinny and perfect and it just makes me upset cause I 
know I will never have a face like theirs and I do think I look ugly 
compared to those girls... But there's still that part of me who keeps 
hoping and I hate it cause I always am too shy to admit to liking someone 
and I know I would get turned down if I did admit my crush to him... But (i 
know i keep saying 'but' ahh) I've talked to some family about my 
insecurities and now that I've seen this video I've realised that you don't 
need a confirmation from men to feel pretty, or even beautiful. It's all 
about yourself, and how you walk through life. You've gotta have that 
sparkle in your eyes when you smile to know you're good with who you are. 
Atleast, that's what I think. You've gotta *shine*. And I will remember 
that from now on. Shine and sparkle ladies.﻿
comments.author: purplecandyfloss

comments.text:
How to feel beautiful, you ask? Detach yourself completely from people's 
opinions, the good and the bad: if the good opinions of people will "make 
your day" then their bad opinions will affect you to the same degree, but 
the difference is the effect is negative: they'll ruin your day. You can't 
lie to yourself and say "Oh I feel confident when people compliment me, but 
I don't care what they say negatively about me!" No, you do care. You try 
not to, but you do. Denial won't do, detaching yourself completely from 
other people's good and bad opinions will do. You being your own source of 
self esteem will do.﻿

comments.author: PLC Studios

comments.text:
Regarding "surrounding yourself with people who..."
Other people isn't something we can control. I go back and forth daily on 
'yes, I feel pretty/beautiful' and 'no, i don't'.  Even when you surround 
yourself with people who you know care about you.... how many can that 
really be? How many people do you come into contact with that really truly 
care about what makes you who you are?
And even family, as much as they love you, can make you feel like you're 
lacking.
It's difficult in this life to hold onto whatever value you can assign 
yourself.. and made even more difficult when you have to factor in how 
other people value you.
Bottom line: it's hard no matter what. The best we can do is hold our heads 
up and go for it. If someone doesn't like it, someone else will. The 
question is, "Do you like it?"﻿

comments.text:
Well, I think that guys have it MUCH harder, in terms of looks.

Women, in general, have more control in who they want their partner to be, 
and can change more aspects of their appearance to suit society, than men 
can.

If men have a 10 centimetre penis, I think that he'd be rejected a lot more 
by women than a man would on breast size. Granted, there aren't many that 
would objectify a man on his manhood, and look past that, but I am speaking 
for the majority. Even if a woman was flat-chested, she could get breast 
implants. If a man has a 10 centimetre penis, then there is next to nothing 
he can do. He has to play the cards, that he was dealt.

Yes, that guy with a small penis will learn how to master oral sex, but 
that doesn't stop a man with a Ron Jeremy sized penis from becoming an oral 
sex master as well.

Men have less criteria for a mate, rather than women. I know many men that 
will touch anything that has two legs, and is breathing. I don't think 
there are women that are that way, and if there was, I have yet to meet 
one, and I have met MANY women.

I have seen many women post pictures of men, with muscular builds, and say 
sexual things about them. 

I am sick of the objectifying shown by shallow women. It isn't helping that 
there is a movement that tries for equal rights for women? It's called 
Feminism? Hypocrisy is all I see.

I am sorry, but this what I see.

PS, do not say that I have a micropenis or anything related, as I do not 
have one. I am about 15 cm in length, and about 13 cm around. Average.﻿
